ygData.subject: Re: ACID REST-HTTP
ygData.msgSnippet: The context of this discussion was whether SOAP is superior to REST-HTTP because it specifies ACID/MQ services.  My point is that if we put in a little work we

The context of this discussion was whether SOAP is superior to REST-HTTP 
because it specifies ACID/MQ services.  My point is that if we put in a 
little work we can specify the same services on top of HTTP/SMTP and reuse 
more of our installed based of software while simultaneously avoiding the 
complexity of SOAP.

The implementation details of transaction managers/monitors, ease of 
development, long/dropped transactions, and prioritization are really 
implementation or application issues not protocol issues.  If someone has a 
reliable client, they don't need a separate HTTP transaction manager 
server.  Control of sub-transactions can be as easy as editing a list of 
current commits/rollbacks, but that is really an IDE question and not a 
protocol one.
There are millions of shopping carts abandoned everyday across the 
Internet.  How you handle this issue depends on your site. etc.

I am suggesting the HTTP/SMTP equivalent of ODBC.  That MS Access exposes 
ODBC but does not implement two-phase-commit may be a problem with MS 
Access, but it is not a problem with ODBC.  Similarly, that you may want a 
separate transaction manager for ACID-HTTP is not an objection to 
ACID-HTTP, it is just one of your particular implementation issues.

-Alex-
